page.title: 04THE PAPIL STONE
page.content: IN 1880, A SCULPTURED STONE FROM THE CHURCHYARD IN PAPIL WAS GIVEN TO THE SCOTTISH NATIONAL MUSEUM IN EDINBURGH WITH PERMISSION FROM THE PEOPLE WHO OWNED BURRA AT THAT TIME. PAPIL WAS ONE OF THE FIRST PLACES IN BRITAIN WHERE A CHURCH WAS BUILT. THE PAPIL STONE WAS A GRAVE STONE FOR SOMEONE, PROBABLY A PRIEST. THE STONE IS DECORATED WITH INTERLACED CELTIC CROSSES AS WELL AS ANIMALS, MONSTERS AND RELIGIOUS FIGURES. RESEARCHERS THINK THAT ALL THE SAINTS HAD THEIR OWN ANIMAL SIGNS AND THAT THE LION ON THE STONE SHOWS THAT THE PRIEST WHO DIED WAS A FOLLOWER OF ST,MARK. THE NAME PAPIL HAS SURVIVED FROM THE TIME BEFORE THE VIKINGS INVADED.
